New Records: Paul Skenes became just the second player since 1913 to post a sub-2.00 ERA through 22 career appearances, joining Steve Rogers.
He achieved the latter feat in large part because of his changeup, an infrequently deployed offering that proved downright devastating for Cincinnati’s hitters.
Skenes upped his strikeout total to 167 on the year, the fifth-most by a pitcher in their first 22 appearances since 2001.
Key Match Events: Paul Skenes struck out nine hitters across five scoreless innings in the Pirates' 2-0 win against the Reds.
The Pirates' bullpen was really good, pitched a shutout, and this ballpark is really challenging.
Aroldis Chapman recorded two strikeouts, the last of which gave him 94 on the season, and he is now tied for the most strikeouts in a single season by a left-handed Pirates reliever.
Pre-Game Insights: Manager Derek Shelton said the plan going into the game was to have Skenes throw only five innings as part of managing the rookie’s workload.
Shelton commended Skenes for continuing to evolve and improve throughout his rookie year.
Post-Match Reflections: Skenes said it would be pretty cool to win the Rookie of the Year award, especially in his first professional season.
Bart said Skenes’ changeup reminds him of the one two-time All-Star Kevin Gausman throws.
Shelton said he thinks Skenes deserves to be a winner of the Rookie of the Year award.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Pirates struck again four innings later on another homer, this one marking the first of Nick Yorke’s young MLB career.
Yorke said he knew it was gone off the bat and ambushed the first-pitch heater to start the inning and got one over the plate that he can handle.
Others: The Pirates have gone 5-5 against the Brewers this season, including a 2-2 record at home.
The Brewers have already clinched a playoff spot with their second straight National League Central title.
